Edward Grimeston’s role in continuing Knolles’ narrative for the years from 1610 to 1620 is still something of a mystery. He was apparently a famous English translator during the reign of Elizabeth i (1558–1603) and James i (1603–1625) who translated a number of classical and contemporary histories, especially those of great European kingdoms and empires. He had access to a variety of primary documents in Dutch, French and Italian. He presumably used these documents to compose an original account of events in Ottoman history of the early seventeenth century rather than translating any extant narrative
